'''''Strobilomyces foveatus''''' is a little-known species of [[fungus]] in the [[Boletaceae]] family. It was first reported by mycologist [[E.J.H. Corner]] in 1972, from specimens he collected in Malaysia in 1959, and has since been found in Australia. [[Basidiocarp|Fruit bodies]] are characterized by the small dark brown to black conical scales covering the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], and the net-like pattern of ridges on the upper stem. The roughly spherical [[spore]]s measure about eight [[micrometre]]s, and are densely covered with slender conical spines. The [[edible mushroom|edibility]] of this species is unknown.

==Taxonomy and classification==
''Strobilomyces foveatus'' was first described scientifically by mycologist [[E.J.H. Corner]] in 1972, from specimens collected in [[Sarawak]], Malaysia in 1959.<ref name=Corner1972/> It was one of several new ''[[Strobilomyces]]'' species he described in his [[monograph]] of Malaysian Boletaceae—the others were ''[[Strobilomyces annulatus|S. annulatus]]'', ''[[Strobilomyces mirandus|S. mirandus]]'', and  ''[[Strobilomyces mollis|S. mollis]]''.<ref name=IndexofFungi/>

The fungus is [[Biological classification|classified]] in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Strobilomyces'' of the genus ''[[Strobilomyces]]''. Species in this section are characterized by having [[spore]]s that may be either smooth or with short spines or warts, ridges or reticulations. The ornamentation is reduced or absent in the suprahilar region (a depressed area near the [[wikt:hilar appendage|hilar appendage]]).<ref name=Singer1986/> The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''foveatus'' is derived from the [[Latin]] adjective ''foveola'', referring to a surface with pits or depressions.<ref name=Headrick2001/>

==Description==

The [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] are between {{convert|7|to|10|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, with a convex shape. The cap surface is covered with dark brown to black erect scales between 1.5–3 by 1.5–2.5 mm. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is up to {{convert|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} long; it is {{convert|1.2|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick at the top, and {{convert|1.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick at the bottom. The surface of the upper stem is strongly reticulate (covered with a network-like pattern) with individual meshes about 2–4 mm wide and 1–2 mm deep. The pores on the underside of the cap are between 0.5–1 mm wide, dirty white then gray, and they bruise a brownish-black color. The tubes which make up the pores are up to {{convert|1.2|cm|in|abbr=on}} long. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thick and initially white, but will stain a brownish-black after exposure to the air.<ref name=Corner1972/>

The [[spore]]s are 8–10 by 6.3–8.3 [[micrometre|μm]], and densely covered with slender conical spines about 0.5 μm tall. The abundant [[wikt:pleurocystidium|pleurocystidia]] (large sterile cells found on gill faces) are thin-walled, measuring up to 90 μm long by 1–20 μm wide, and [[wikt:ventricose|ventricose]] (with a swelling on one side), with a narrow appendage up to 20 μm by 4–8 μm. The [[hypha]]e that make up the [[pileipellis|cap surface]] and the warts are branched, loosely interwoven, and sooty colored; the [[clamp connection|unclamped]] cells typically measure 17–45 by 9–26 μm. The surface of the stem is made of a compact mat of hyphae roughly 120 μm thick, that reduces to a sterile [[hymenium]] in the upper part of the stem.<ref name=Corner1972/>

Corner notes that the species "may be identical" with ''[[Strobilomyces echinatus]]'' Beeli, an African species with spores that measure 9.5–13 by 6.3–8.3 μm.<ref name=Corner1972/>

==Habitat and distribution==
[[image:Sarawak state locator.svg|thumb|right|The province of [[Sarawak]] (red) in [[Malaysia]] ]]
Corner collected specimens growing in [[humus]] on the forest floor, in [[Bako National Park]] ({{coord|1|43|N|110|28|E|region:MY_type:landmark_source:GNS-enwiki|display=inline,title}}) in [[Sarawak]], Malaysia, in northern [[Borneo]].<ref name=Corner1972/> It has also been collected from southern [[Queensland]] in Australia.<ref name="urlmushroomobserver.org"/> Although it is not known definitively for ''Strobilomyces foveatus'', all ''Strobilomyces'' species are suspected to be [[mycorrhiza]]l.<ref name=Singer1986/>
